title: 106_hr30
content: The Financial Information Privacy Act of 1999, also known as the Consumer Credit Protection Act, includes provisions for privacy protection of customer information of financial institutions. It covers definitions, administrative enforcement, civil liability, criminal penalties, relation to State laws, and agency guidance. The Financial Information Privacy Act of 1999 defines key terms related to customer information of financial institutions, including 'customer,' 'customer information of a financial institution,' and 'document.' The Financial Information Privacy Act of 1999 defines 'financial institution' as any entity providing financial services to customers with accounts, including depository institutions, loan companies, credit card issuers, and consumer reporting agencies. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may further define this term. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may prescribe regulations to further define the term 'financial institution' for this title. "Privacy protection for customer information of financial institutions is addressed in Section 1003." Prohibition on obtaining customer information by false pretenses is a violation under this title. It involves making false statements to deceive financial institution officers or customers into disclosing customer information. It is a violation to deceive financial institution officers or customers into releasing customer information by providing false documents or making false statements. The section prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution knowingly or avoiding knowing that the person will use it improperly. Law enforcement agencies are exempt from this provision, as are financial institutions when testing security procedures. The section prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution for improper use, with exemptions for law enforcement agencies and financial institutions testing security procedures. No provision prevents obtaining customer information available as a public record under securities laws. SEC. 1004. ADMINISTRATIVE ENFORCEMENT. Enforcement of compliance with this title will be overseen by the Federal Trade Commission, similar to its enforcement powers under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. In certain cases, enforcement may also fall under the jurisdiction of other agencies such as the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency for national banks and the Federal Reserve System for member banks. The Board oversees non-national banks, branches, and agencies of foreign banks, commercial lending companies owned by foreign banks, and organizations under the Federal Reserve Act. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation oversees banks insured by them and insured State branches of foreign banks. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation oversees banks insured by them and insured State branches of foreign banks. Violations of this title are treated as violations of other laws by relevant agencies such as the Office of Thrift Supervision and the National Credit Union Administration. Each agency mentioned in the previous paragraph has the authority to enforce compliance with the title by using any other authority granted by law. States can also take action against violations by bringing a lawsuit in federal or other courts. States have the right to bring lawsuits on behalf of residents to recover damages for violations, with a maximum of $1,000 per violation. They are also entitled to costs and attorney fees if successful. Prior notice must be given to federal regulators before taking action. The State must provide prior notice to federal regulators before taking action. The Federal Trade Commission or an agency described in subsection (b) has the right to intervene in the action, be heard on all matters, remove the action to the appropriate US district court, and file petitions for appeal. Investigatory powers are granted for bringing any action. Investigatory powers allow state officials to conduct investigations and compel witnesses or evidence. States are limited in taking action if the Federal Trade Commission has initiated a civil action. The Federal Trade Commission or state agencies can bring legal action against defendants for violations of this title as alleged in a complaint. SEC. 1005. CIVIL LIABILITY. "Any person failing to comply with this title regarding a financial institution or customer information is liable for actual damages sustained by the institution or customer, or any amount received by the non-compliant person. Additional damages may also be imposed." The court may allow additional damages. Attorneys' fees are awarded in successful actions to enforce liability under the mentioned paragraphs. SEC. 1006 outlines criminal penalties for violating section 1003, including fines and imprisonment for up to 5 years. Enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases involving violations of other laws or illegal activities exceeding $100,000 in a 12-month period. SEC. 1007 states that this title does not override state laws unless they are inconsistent with it. State laws providing greater protection than this title are not considered inconsistent. SEC. 1008 addresses agency guidance. SEC. 1008 requires Federal banking agencies to issue advisories to depository institutions to help prevent and detect prohibited activities. The Comptroller General of the United States, in consultation with relevant agencies, must submit a report to Congress within 18 months on the effectiveness of remedies for fraudulent attempts to obtain financial information and recommend any necessary legislative or regulatory actions to address privacy threats.
